1.verse: In the past God spoke to our fathers at different times and in various ways through the prophets,

2.verse: but in these final days he has spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed the heir of all things, through whom he also created the material universe.

3.verse: This Son is the radiance of his glory and the exact representation of his nature, and although sustaining all there is by the word of his power, yet made purification for sins, and then sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high,

4.verse: having been exalted as far above the angels as the name he inherited is more noble than theirs.

5.verse: For to which of the angels did God ever say, “My Son are you! Today I have fathered you”? Or again, “I will be to him a father, and he shall be to me a son”?

6.verse: And again, when he brings the firstborn into the world, he says, “Let all the angels of God worship him.”

7.verse: Regarding the angels he says, “He makes his angels winds, and his ministers a flame of fire.”

8.verse: But regarding the Son he says, “Your throne, O God, is for all time, and the scepter of absolute justice is the scepter of your kingdom.

9.verse: You have loved righteousness and hated lawlessness; therefore God, your God, has anointed you with the oil of gladness beyond your companions.”

10.verse: And, “In the beginning, Lord, you laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the works of your hands.

11.verse: They will perish; but you continue. And all of them like a garment will wear out,

12.verse: like a robe you will fold them up, like a garment they will also be changed. But you are the same, and your years will never end.”

13.verse: And to which of the angels has he ever said, “Sit at my right hand until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet”?

14.verse: Are they not all ministering spirits sent out to serve for the sake of those who are to inherit salvation?

1.verse: Therefore we must pay much closer attention to what we have heard, lest we drift away from it.

2.verse: For if the message spoken through angels became firmly established and every transgression and disobedience received a just penalty,

3.verse: how will we escape if we neglect such a great salvation? Which at first was declared by the Lord, and it was attested to us by those who heard,

4.verse: while God supported their testimony by signs and wonders and various miracles, and by gifts of the Holy Spirit distributed according to his will.

5.verse: Now it was not to angels that God subjected the world to come, about which we are speaking.

6.verse: But someone has testified somewhere, “What is man that you take thought for him, or the son of man, that you care for him?

7.verse: You made him for a little while lower than the angels; you crowned him with glory and honor,

8.verse: You put everything in subjection under his feet.” Now in putting everything in subjection to him, he left nothing outside his control. But in fact we do not yet see everything under his control.

9.verse: But we do see Jesus, who for a little while was made lower than the angels, so that by the grace of God he might taste death for everyone, because of the suffering of death crowned with glory and honor.

10.verse: For it was appropriate that God, for whom and through whom all things exist, in bringing many sons to glory, should make the champion of their salvation perfect through suffering.

11.verse: For the one who sanctifies and those who are sanctified are all of one origin. That is why Jesus is not ashamed to call them brothers,

12.verse: when he says, “I will proclaim your name to my brothers; in the midst of the congregation I will sing your praise.”

13.verse: And again, “I will put my trust in him.” And again, “Here I am and the children whom God has given me.”

14.verse: Therefore since the children share in blood and flesh, he himself also, in the same way, shared the same things so that by his death he might destroy the one who holds the power of death (that is, the devil),

15.verse: and liberate those who through all their life were held in slavery by their fear of death.

16.verse: For surely he does not reach out to help angels, but he reaches out to help the seed of Abraham.

17.verse: Therefore he was obligated to become like his brothers in every respect, so that he could become a merciful and faithful high priest in the service of God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people.

18.verse: For because he himself suffered when tempted, he is able to come to the aid of those who are being tempted.

1.verse: For this reason, holy brothers, you who share in the heavenly calling, consider that the apostle and high priest of whom our confession speaks, Jesus,

2.verse: was faithful to the one who appointed him in all his house, as Moses also was.

3.verse: For Jesus has been counted worthy of greater glory than Moses, just as the builder of a house has greater honor than the house itself.

4.verse: For every house is built by someone, but the one who built everything is God.

5.verse: Now Moses was faithful in all God’s household as a servant, bearing witness to those things that would be spoken later,

6.verse: but Christ is faithful as the Son, presiding over God’s household, and we are his household if indeed we hold firmly to our confidence and the hope of which we boast.

7.verse: Therefore just as the Holy Spirit says, “Today, if you hear his voice,

8.verse: do not harden your hearts as you did in the rebellion, on the day of testing in the wilderness

9.verse: where your fathers put me to the test through their distrust, though they had seen my works

10.verse: for forty years. Therefore I was angry with this generation and said, ‘They are always going astray in their hearts, and they have not known my ways.’

11.verse: So I swore in my anger, ‘They shall certainly not enter my rest.’

12.verse: Be careful, brothers, lest there be in any of you an evil, unbelieving heart that turns away from the living God.

13.verse: But encourage one another every day, as long as it is called “today,” that none of you may be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin.

14.verse: For we have become partners of Christ, if in fact we hold the beginning of our confidence firm to the end.

15.verse: As it is said, “Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts as you did in the rebellion.”

16.verse: For who were they who heard and rebelled? Were they not really all those who came out of Egypt led by Moses?

17.verse: And with whom was he angry for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose bodies fell in the wilderness?

18.verse: And to whom did he swear that they would not enter his rest, except those who had refused to obey?

19.verse: So then we see that they were unable to enter because of unbelief.

1.verse: Therefore while the promise of entering his rest is still open, let us fear lest any one of you may seem to be excluded from it.

2.verse: For we also had good news proclaimed to us just as they did; but the word they heard did not benefit those who were not united with those who listened in faith

3.verse: For we who have believed do enter that rest, just as God has said, “As I swore in my anger, ‘They shall certainly not enter my rest,’” and yet his work has been completed since the foundation of the world

4.verse: For somewhere he has spoken of the seventh day in this manner: “And God rested on the seventh day from all his works.”

5.verse: And furthermore in this context he said, “They shall certainly not enter my rest.”

6.verse: Therefore since it remains for some to enter it, and those who previously had the good news proclaimed to them failed to enter because of disobedience,

7.verse: God again ordains a certain day—“today”—saying through David, after so long a time, just as it has been said before, “Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts.”

8.verse: For if Joshua had given them rest, God would not have spoken of another time after that.

9.verse: Consequently there remains a Sabbath rest for the people of God.

10.verse: For the one who enters God’s rest has also rested from his works, as God did from his.

11.verse: Let us, therefore, make every effort to enter that rest; otherwise one of you might fall by the same sort of disobedience.

12.verse: For the word of God is living and effective, sharper than any two-edged sword, cutting through so as to divide soul from spirit, joints from marrow. It is even able to discern the thoughts and deliberations of the heart.

13.verse: And nothing in creation is hidden from God’s sight, but everything is uncovered and exposed to the eyes of the one to whom we must give account.

14.verse: Therefore since we have a great high priest who has gone through the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us continue to hold fast to our confession.

15.verse: For we do not have a high priest who is unable to feel our weaknesses, but one who has been tempted in every way just as we are—yet without sin.

16.verse: Therefore let us approach with confidence the throne of grace, so that we may receive mercy and find grace for help when we need it.

1.verse: For every high priest, being chosen from among men, is appointed on behalf of men to represent them in matters related to God, to offer gifts and sacrifices for sins.

2.verse: He is able to deal compassionately with the ignorant and going astray, since he too is subject to weakness.

3.verse: That is why he is obligated to offer sacrifice for his own sins, just as he does for the sins of the people.

4.verse: And no one takes this honor on his own accord, but receives it when called by God, just as Aaron also was.

5.verse: So also Christ did not exalt himself to become high priest, but was appointed by the one who said to him, “You are my Son, today I have become your Father”;

6.verse: as also in another place God says, “You are a priest for all time according to the order of Melchizedek.”

7.verse: In the days of his flesh, Jesus offered up prayers and supplications, with loud crying and tears, to the one who was able to save him from death, and he was heard because of his godly fear.

8.verse: Although he was a son, he learned obedience from what he suffered.

9.verse: And once made perfect, he became for all those who obey him the source of eternal salvation,

10.verse: having been designated by God a high priest according to the order of Melchizedek.

11.verse: On this subject we have much to say and it is hard to explain, since you have become sluggish in understanding.

12.verse: For though by this time you ought to be teachers, you have need of someone to teach you again the basic elements of God’s revelation. You have become people having need of milk, not solid food;

13.verse: for everyone who lives on milk is inexperienced with the teaching about righteousness, since he is still a child.

14.verse: But solid food is for the mature, for those who by virtue of their maturity have senses that are trained to distinguish good from evil.

1.verse: Therefore let us leave standing the elementary teaching about Christ and let us move on to maturity, not laying again a foundation of repentance from dead works and of faith in God,

2.verse: instruction about cleansing rites and laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment.

3.verse: And we will do this, if God permits.

4.verse: For it is impossible when those who have once been enlightened and have tasted the heavenly gift and have become partakers of the Holy Spirit

5.verse: and have tasted the goodness of God’s word and the powers of the coming age

6.verse: and have committed apostasy, to restore them to repentance, since to their own harm they are crucifying the Son of God again and exposing him to public shame.

7.verse: For the field that soaks up the frequent rain that falls on it and yields a crop useful for those for whom it is cultivated, receives a blessing from God.

8.verse: But if it produces thorns and thistles, it is useless and about to be cursed; its fate is to be burned.

9.verse: But we are convinced of better things in your case, beloved—things that accompany salvation—even though we speak as we do.

10.verse: For God is not so unjust as to forget your work and the love you have demonstrated for his cause, when you served and continue to serve fellow believers.

11.verse: But we want each one of you to demonstrate the same earnestness to the very end for the fulfillment of your hope,

12.verse: so that you will not be lazy, but imitators of those who by faith and perseverance inherit the promises.

13.verse: When God made a promise to Abraham, since he had no one greater by whom to swear, he swore by himself,

14.verse: saying, “Surely I will bless you greatly and increase your descendants abundantly.”

15.verse: And thus by patient endurance, Abraham received what had been promised.

16.verse: For people swear by someone greater than themselves, and the oath confirms what is said and puts to an end all dispute.

17.verse: Because God wanted to show more clearly to the heirs of the promise the unchanging nature of his purpose, he confirmed it with an oath,

18.verse: so that through two unchangeable facts, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have taken refuge might have strong incentive to hold fast to the hope set before us.

19.verse: We have this hope as an anchor for life, both sure and steadfast—a hope that enters the inner shrine behind the veil,

20.verse: where Jesus has entered on our behalf as forerunner, having become a high priest for all time according to the order of Melchizedek.

1.verse: For this Melchizedek, king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, met Abraham returning from the defeat of the kings and blessed him,

2.verse: and to him Abraham alloted a tenth part of everything. Translated, his name means first, “king of righteousness,” then it also means, “king of Salem,” that is, “king of peace.”

3.verse: He is without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life; but like the Son of God he continues a priest for all time.

4.verse: But see how great this man was to whom the patriarch Abraham gave a tithe of the finest plunder.

5.verse: And those of the sons of Levi who receive the priestly office have a mandate according to the law to collect a tithe from the people, that is, from their fellow countrymen, although they too come from the loins of Abraham.

6.verse: But this man who does not trace his descent from them received tithes from Abraham and blessed the one who had the promises.

7.verse: It is without any dispute that the person of lesser status is blessed by the one of greater status.

8.verse: In the one case, mortal men receive tithes, but in the other case, by one of whom it is testified that he lives.

9.verse: And it could be said that Levi himself, who receives tithes, paid tithes through Abraham,

10.verse: for he was still in the loins of his ancestor when Melchizedek met Abraham.

11.verse: If, then, perfection had been attainable through the Levitical priesthood (for under it the people had received the law), what further need would there have been for another kind of priest to arise according to the order of Melchizedek, rather than one designated after the order of Aaron?

12.verse: For whenever the priesthood is altered, there is necessarily an alteration in the law as well.

13.verse: For the one of whom these things are said belongs to a different tribe, from which no one has ever served at the altar.

14.verse: For it is perfectly clear that our Lord is descended from Judah, and in regard to that tribe Moses said nothing about priests.

15.verse: And it is even more obvious that if, according to the likeness of Melchizedek, another priest arises,

16.verse: he does so not on the basis of a law expressed in a carnal commandment, but on the basis of the power of an indestructible life.

17.verse: For it is attested of him, “You are a priest for all time, according to the order of Melchizedek.”

18.verse: For there is an annulment of a former commandment because of its weakness and uselessness

19.verse: (for the law made nothing perfect); but the introduction of a better hope through which we draw near to God.

20.verse: And since this was not done without an oath (for others have become priests without an oath,

21.verse: but he became a priest with an oath by the one who said to him, “The Lord has sworn and will not change his mind, ‘You are a priest for all time’”

22.verse: accordingly Jesus has become the guarantor of a better covenant.

23.verse: Now on the one hand, these many have become priests because they were hindered by death from continuing in office,

24.verse: but on the other hand, Jesus, because he remains for all time, has a priesthood that is permanent.

25.verse: Consequently, he is able to save completely those who draw near to God through him, because he continually lives to intercede for them.

26.verse: For such a high priest was appropriate for us, one who is holy, innocent, undefiled; having been separated from sinners, he became exalted above the heavens.

27.verse: He has no need to offer up daily sacrifices, like those other high priests, first for their own sins and then for the sins of the people, for this he did once for all when he offered up himself.

28.verse: For the law appoints men as high priests who have weaknesses, but the word of the oath, which came later than the law, appoints the Son who has been made perfect for all time.

1.verse: Now the crowning affirmation to what we are saying is this: we do have such a high priest, who has taken his seat at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in heaven,

2.verse: an officiating priest of holy things and of the true tabernacle which the Lord put up, not man.

3.verse: For every high priest is appointed to offer both gifts and sacrifices; so it was necessary for this high priest also to have something to offer.

4.verse: So if he had been on earth, he would not be a priest, since there are already those who offer the gifts prescribed by the law.

5.verse: The place where they serve is a shadowy suggestion of the heavenly sanctuary, just as Moses was warned by God when he was about to erect the tabernacle; for he said, “See that you make everything according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.”

6.verse: But as it is, he has obtained a superior ministry, since the covenant of which he is mediator is better, since it has been enacted on the basis of better promises.

7.verse: For if that first covenant had been blameless, then no occasion would have been sought for a second.

8.verse: For finding fault, God says to them, “Behold, days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will establish a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah.

9.verse: It will not be like the covenant that I made with their fathers on the day when I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt, because they did not continue in my covenant and I abandoned them, says the Lord.

10.verse: For this is the covenant that I will establish with the house of Israel after those days, declares the Lord: I will put my laws in their minds and I will inscribe them on their hearts. I will be their God and they will be my people.

11.verse: And they will not teach each one his neighbor and each one his brother saying, ‘Know the Lord,’ for they will all know me from the least of them to the greatest.

12.verse: For I will be gracious toward their iniquities and I will never again remember their sins.”

13.verse: In speaking of a new covenant, he makes the first one obsolete. And what is becoming obsolete and growing old is ready to disappear.

1.verse: Now the first covenant, in fact, had regulations for worship and also an earthly sanctuary.

2.verse: For a tent was set up. The outer room, in which were the lampstand and the table and the consecrated bread, was called “the Holy Place.”

3.verse: Behind the curtain was a second room, a shrine called “the Most Holy Place.”

4.verse: It contained the golden altar of incense and the ark of the covenant covered on all sides with gold, in which were the golden urn containing the manna, Aaron’s rod that had budded, and the stone tablets of the covenant.

5.verse: Above it were the cherubim of glory overshadowing the place of forgiveness. Of these things we cannot now speak in detail.

6.verse: When these things had been prepared in this way, the priests used to enter regularly into the outer room to perform their ritual services;

7.verse: however into the second room only the high priest entered, and that only once a year, and not without taking blood, which he offered for himself and for the sins committed unintentionally by the people.

8.verse: By this the Holy Spirit is showing that the way into the real sanctuary had not yet been disclosed as long as the first tent was standing.

9.verse: This is an illustration pointing to the present time, during which the gifts and sacrifices being offered cannot perfect the worshiper so far as his conscience is concerned,

10.verse: but deal only with food and drink and various ceremonial washings, regulations for the body imposed until the time of correction.

11.verse: But when Christ appeared as high priest of the good things that have now come, passing through the greater and more perfect tent (not made with hands, that is, not of this creation),

12.verse: he entered once for all into the Most Holy Place, not by means of the blood of goats and calves, but by means of his own blood, thus obtaining an eternal redemption.

13.verse: For if the blood of goats and bulls, and the sprinkled ashes of a heifer, sanctify those who have been ceremonially defiled so that their flesh is purified,

14.verse: how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself without blemish to God, purify our conscience from dead works to worship the living God!

15.verse: And for this reason he is the mediator of a new covenant, so that those who are called may receive the promised eternal inheritance, since a death has occurred that redeems them from the transgressions committed under that first covenant.

16.verse: For where there is a covenant, it is required that the death of the one who made it be established.

17.verse: For a will takes effect only when a person has died; it cannot possibly be valid so long as the one who made it is still alive.

18.verse: Therefore not even the first covenant was inaugurated without blood.

19.verse: For when every commandment of the law had been declared by Moses to all the people, taking the blood of calves and goats together with water and scarlet wool and hyssop, he sprinkled both the book itself and all the people,

20.verse: saying, “This is the blood of the covenant which God ordained for you.”

21.verse: And in the same way he sprinkled with blood both the tent and all the vessels used in worship.

22.verse: In fact, according to the law almost everything is sprinkled with blood, and without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness.

23.verse: Thus it was necessary that earthly copies of the heavenly realities be purified by these rites, but the heavenly realities themselves with better sacrifices than these.

24.verse: For Christ did not enter a sanctuary made with hands, that was a mere copy of the true one, but into heaven itself, now to appear in the presence of God on our behalf.

25.verse: Nor was it to offer himself repeatedly, as the high priest enters the Most Holy Place every year with blood not his own,

26.verse: for then he would have had to suffer again and again since the foundation of the world. But as it is, he has appeared once for all at the climax of the ages to put away sin by his sacrifice.

27.verse: And just as it is appointed for mortals to die once, and after that to experience judgment,

28.verse: so also Christ, after having been offered once to bear the sins of many, will appear a second time to those who are eagerly awaiting him, without reference to sin but for salvation.

1.verse: For since the law is but a shadow of the good things to come and not the actual form of those realities, it can never perfect those who draw near by the same sacrifices which they offer continuously year after year.

2.verse: For otherwise would they not have ceased being offered, since the worshipers, once cleansed, would have no consciousness of sins?

3.verse: But in these sacrifices there is a reminder of sins year after year.

4.verse: For it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.

5.verse: Therefore when he came into the world, he said, “Sacrifice and offering you did not desire, but a body you prepared for me.

6.verse: You did not take pleasure in whole burnt offerings and sin-offerings.

7.verse: Then I said, ‘Behold, I have come—in the scroll of a book it is written about me—to do your will, O God.’”

8.verse: After he said what I just quoted, “Sacrifices and offerings and whole burnt offerings and sin-offerings you did not desire nor did you take pleasure in them” (namely those offered according to the law),

9.verse: then he added, “Behold, I have come to do your will.” He does away with the first in order to establish the second.

10.verse: By that will we have been made holy through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.

11.verse: Furthermore, every priest stands day after day performing his religious duties, offering repeatedly the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins.

12.verse: But when this priest had offered a single sacrifice for sins for all time, he sat down at the right hand of God,

13.verse: waiting from that time until his enemies are placed as a footstool for his feet,

14.verse: because by a single offering he has perfected for all time those who are being made holy.

15.verse: And the Holy Spirit also witnesses to us, for after saying,

16.verse: “This is the covenant that I will establish with them after those days, declares the Lord; I will put my laws in their hearts and I will inscribe them on their minds,”

17.verse: then he says, “Their sins and their lawless acts I will never again remember.”

18.verse: Now where there is forgiveness of these, there is no longer any offering for sin.

19.verse: Therefore, brothers, since we have confidence to enter the holy place by the blood of Jesus,

20.verse: a way that is new and living, which he opened for us through the curtain, that is, through his flesh,

21.verse: and since we have a great priest in charge of the house of God,

22.verse: let us continue to draw near with a sincere heart in full assurance of faith, since our hearts have been sprinkled clean from a guilty conscience and our bodies washed with clean water.

23.verse: Let us continue to hold fast the hope that we confess without wavering, for the one who made the promise is faithful.

24.verse: And let us take thought of how to spur one another on to love and good works,

25.verse: not abandoning our own meetings, as is the habit of some, but rather encouraging one another, and all the more since you see the Day drawing near.

26.verse: For if we deliberately persist in sin after receiving the knowledge of the truth, there is no longer any sacrifice for sins,

27.verse: but only a terrifying expectation of judgment and of raging fire ready to consume the adversaries.

28.verse: Anyone who violates the law of Moses dies without mercy on the testimony of two or three witnesses.

29.verse: How much greater punishment do you think will be deserved by the one who has trampled the Son of God underfoot, and has profaned the blood of the covenant by which he was made holy, and has insulted the Spirit of grace?

30.verse: For we know the one who said, “Vengeance belongs to me, I will repay,” and again, “The Lord will judge his people.”

31.verse: It is terrifying to fall into the hands of the living God.

32.verse: Instead, remember those former days in which, after you had received the light, you weathered such a difficult struggle with suffering.

33.verse: Sometimes you were made a public spectacle, both by insults and persecutions, and at other times you became one with those who were treated in that way,

34.verse: for in fact you shared the sufferings of those in prison, and with joy accepted the confiscation of your belongings, since you knew that you yourselves had a better and lasting possession.

35.verse: Therefore do not throw away your boldness, which has great reward.

36.verse: You have need of endurance, then, so that after you have done the will of God, you may receive what was promised.

37.verse: For “just a little longer, the one who is coming will arrive; he will not delay.

38.verse: But my righteous one will live by faithfulness. But should he shrink back, my soul will take no pleasure in him.”

39.verse: But we are not of those who shrink back and are lost, but are of those who are faithful and so preserve their soul.

1.verse: Now faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen.

2.verse: For by it the men of the past were approved by God.

3.verse: By faith we understand that the universe was created by the word of God, so that what is seen was not brought into being from anything observable.

4.verse: By faith Abel offered to God a more acceptable sacrifice than Cain, through which faith he was attested as righteous, God himself showing his approval by accepting his gifts. And though he died, he still speaks through his faith.

5.verse: By faith Enoch was taken up so that he did not see death, and he could not be found, because God had taken him. For before he was taken he had been approved as one who had been pleasing to God,

6.verse: and without faith it is impossible to please him, for the one who approaches God must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who seek him.

7.verse: By faith Noah, having been warned by God concerning events as yet unseen, took heed and built an ark for the safety of his household. By this act of faith he condemned humanity and became an heir of the righteousness that comes by faith.

8.verse: By faith Abraham obeyed when he was called to go out to a place which he would receive as an inheritance. He set out even though he did not know where he was going.

9.verse: By faith he migrated to the land he had been promised, as to a foreign land, living in tents as did Isaac and Jacob, heirs with him of the same promise,

10.verse: for he was looking forward to the city which has foundations, whose designer and builder is God.

11.verse: By faith Abraham was enabled to become a father—even though Sarah herself was sterile and beyond the normal age of childbearing—because he regarded as faithful the one who had made the promise.

12.verse: And so it was that from this one man, and he was already impotent, there were born descendants as many as the stars of heaven in number and as innumerable as the grains of sand along the shore of the sea

13.verse: These all died in faith, without receiving the fulfillment of the promises, but they saw them from a distance and greeted them. They acknowledged that they were strangers and exiles in the land.

14.verse: For those who speak in such a way make it clear that they are seeking a land of their own.

15.verse: If they had been referring to that country from which they had set out, they would have had opportunity to return.

16.verse: But as it is, they were longing for a better homeland, that is, a heavenly one. For this reason God is not ashamed to be called their God, for he has prepared a city to receive them.

17.verse: By faith Abraham, when he was being tested, offered up Isaac; yes, he who had received the promises was offering his only son,

18.verse: of whom he had been told, “It is through Isaac that descendants will be named for you.”

19.verse: He considered that God was able to raise him up even from the dead, and, in a sense, he did receive him back from there.

20.verse: By faith Isaac invoked blessings on Jacob and Esau, even regarding things to come.

21.verse: By faith Jacob, while dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph, and bowed in worship, leaning on the top of his staff.

22.verse: By faith Joseph, at the end of his life, spoke about the exodus of the sons of Israel and gave instructions regarding the burial of his bones.

23.verse: By faith Moses, when he was born, was hidden for three months by his parents, because they saw that he was an extraordinary child, and they were not afraid of the king’s edict.

24.verse: By faith Moses, when he was grown up, disdained to be called the son of Pharaoh’s daughter,

25.verse: choosing rather to suffer hardship along with the people of God than to enjoy the transient pleasure of sin.

26.verse: He considered abuse for the sake of Christ greater wealth than the treasures of Egypt, for he was looking ahead to his reward.

27.verse: By faith he left Egypt, not fearing the anger of the king, for he endured as though seeing the one who is invisible.

28.verse: By faith he kept the Passover and the sprinkling of blood, so that the destroying angel would not touch their firstborn.

29.verse: By faith they crossed the Red Sea as if on dry land; but when the Egyptians tried, they were drowned.

30.verse: By faith the walls of Jericho fell down after they had been encircled for seven days.

31.verse: By faith Rahab the prostitute did not perish with the unbelievers, because she had received the spies with peace.

32.verse: And what more shall I say? For time would fail me if I told about Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, about both David and Samuel and the prophets,

33.verse: who through faith conquered kingdoms, brought about justice, obtained what was promised; who shut the mouths of lions,

34.verse: extinguished raging flames, escaped the edge of the sword; who after weakness were made strong, who became mighty in war and put foreign armies to flight.

35.verse: Women received their dead by resurrection. But others were tortured, after refusing to accept release, so that they might gain a better resurrection.

36.verse: Others experienced jeering and flogging, and even chains and prison.

37.verse: They were stoned; they were sawn in two; they were murdered by the sword. They went about in sheepskins and goatskins, destitute, persecuted, mistreated

38.verse: (of whom the world was not worthy). They wandered aimlessly in deserts and on mountains, living in caves and crevices in the ground,

39.verse: and although they all had received commendation for their faith, they did not receive what had been promised,

40.verse: for God had provided something better with us in mind, so that they should not reach their goal apart from us.

1.verse: Therefore since we ourselves have so great a cloud of witnesses surrounding us, let us also lay aside every impediment, and the sin that so easily distracts, and let us run with endurance the race that is prescribed for us,

2.verse: fixing our gaze upon Jesus, the pioneer and perfecter of our faith, who rather than the joy set before him endured a cross, disregarding its shame, and has now taken his seat at the right hand of the throne of God.

3.verse: Consider him who endured from sinners such opposition against himself, so that you may not grow weary in your souls and lose heart.

4.verse: You have not yet resisted to the point of bloodshed as you struggle against sin.

5.verse: And have you forgotten the word of encouragement that speaks to you as sons? “My son, do not regard lightly the discipline of the Lord, nor lose heart when corrected by him.

6.verse: For the Lord disciplines the one he loves, and corrects with punishment everyone whom he receives as a son.”

7.verse: Endure your trials as divine discipline. God is treating you as sons. For what son is there whom a father does not discipline?

8.verse: But if you are left without discipline, in which all sons share, then you are illegitimate children and not sons.

9.verse: Furthermore, we had our natural fathers who disciplined us and we respected them. Should we not much more submit ourselves to the Father of spirits and live?

10.verse: For they disciplined us for a short time as it seemed best to them, but he disciplines us for our benefit, so that we may share his holy character.

11.verse: All discipline at the time seems not to be pleasant, but painful; but later it yields the peaceful fruit of righteousness to those who have been trained by it.

12.verse: Therefore strengthen your drooping hands and weakened knees

13.verse: and make straight paths for your feet, so that what is lame may not be dislocated, but rather healed.

14.verse: Strive for peace with everyone, and for the holiness without which no one will see the Lord.

15.verse: Take care that no one forfeits the grace of God; and that no root of bitterness grows up and causes trouble and by it many are defiled.

16.verse: that no one becomes immoral and profane like Esau, who gave up his inheritance rights in return for a single meal.

17.verse: For you know that even afterward, when he wanted to inherit the blessing, he was rejected, for he found no opportunity for repentance, even though he sought the blessing earnestly with tears.

18.verse: For you have not come to something that can be touched, to a blazing fire, and darkness, and gloom, and a whirlwind;

19.verse: to the blast of a trumpet and a sound of words which made those who heard it beg that no further message be given to them,

20.verse: for they could not endure the order that was given: “If even a wild animal touches the mountain, it shall be stoned.”

21.verse: And so awesome was the spectacle that Moses said, “I am terrified and trembling.”

22.verse: On the contrary, you have come to Mount Zion, even to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to innumerable angels, to a joyful assembly,

23.verse: and to the assembly of the firstborn whose names are inscribed in heaven, and to God, the judge of all, and to the spirits of the righteous who have been made perfect,

24.verse: and to Jesus, mediator of a new covenant, and to sprinkled blood speaking more effectively than the blood of Abel.

25.verse: Take care not to disregard the one who is speaking! For if those did not escape when they disregarded the one who warned them on earth, how much less will we, if we reject the one who warns from heaven.

26.verse: At that time his voice shook the earth, but now he has promised, “Yet once more will I shake not only the earth but also the heaven.”

27.verse: The phrase, “Yet once more,” declares the removal of what can be shaken—that is, created things—so that what cannot be shaken may remain.

28.verse: Therefore since we are receiving a kingdom that cannot be shaken, let us be thankful, and in this way worship God in an acceptable manner, with reverence and awe,

29.verse: for indeed our God is a consuming fire.

2.verse: Do not neglect hospitality to strangers, for by this means some have entertained angels without knowing it.

3.verse: Continue to remember those in prison, as though you were in prison with them, and those who are being mistreated, as though you yourself were suffering bodily.

4.verse: Marriage must be honored by everyone and the marriage bed must be undefiled, for God will judge the sexually immoral and the adulterers.

5.verse: Your conduct must be free from the love of money, and be content with what you have; for God himself has said, “I will never leave you; never will I forsake you.”

6.verse: So we can say with confidence, “The Lord is my helper, I will not be afraid. What can man do to me?”

7.verse: Continue to remember your leaders, those who spoke God’s message to you; reflect on the outcome of their way of life, and imitate their faith.

8.verse: Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and for all time!

9.verse: Do not be swept off your feet by all sorts of strange teachings, for it is good for the heart to be strengthened by grace, not by foods, with which their adherents are not benefited.

10.verse: We have an altar from which those who serve in the tabernacle do not have the right to eat.

11.verse: For while the blood of those animals whose blood is brought into the Most Holy Place by the high priest as a sacrifice for sin, their bodies are burned outside the camp.

12.verse: So Jesus also suffered outside the city gate in order to sanctify the people through his own blood.

13.verse: So then, let us go to him outside the camp, bearing the reproach he bore.

14.verse: For here we have no permanent city, but we are looking forward to the city that is to come.

15.verse: Through him, therefore, let us continually offer up to God a sacrifice of praise, that is to say, the fruit of lips acknowledging his name.

16.verse: And do not neglect doing good and sharing with others, for with sacrifices like that God is pleased.

17.verse: Continue to obey your leaders and submit to them, for they keep watch over your souls as those who must give an account. Let them do this with joy, and not with groaning, for that would be of no advantage to you.

18.verse: Continue to pray for us, for we are convinced that we have a clear conscience, desiring to conduct ourselves honorably in every way.

19.verse: I urge you to do this more than ever so that I may be restored to you sooner.

20.verse: And may the God of peace, who, by the blood of the eternal covenant, brought up from the dead the great shepherd of the sheep, our Lord Jesus,

21.verse: make you complete with everything good to do his will, accomplishing in us that which is pleasing in his sight, through Jesus Christ, to whom be glory for all time. Amen.

22.verse: I appeal to you, brothers, bear with my word of exhortation, for in fact I have written to you briefly.

23.verse: Know that our brother Timothy has been set free. If he arrives soon, I will visit you with him.

24.verse: Greet all your leaders and all the saints. Those from Italy greet you.

25.verse: Grace be with all of you.
